Metallosalen presents very important applications in both homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis. Correspondingly, porous polymeric metallosalen combined with the performance of organometallics and heterogeneous polymers possess potential in CO2 fixation reactions. Herein, a family collection of K@SCs were conceived and obtained by combining cobalt-salen complexes with different groups and diaminobenzene-18-crown-6 complexed with KI, which allows multiphase catalytic immobilization of CO2 to epoxides. Catalyst K@SC-3 can fix CO2 into a variety of substituted epoxides in >90% yields to the corresponding cyclic carbonates in co-catalyst-free and solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, K@SC-3 can be recovered and reused at least six times by simple centrifugal separation, demonstrating superior stability. The kinetics experiments were also carried out at varied temperatures catalyzed by K@SC-3. It is concluded that a first-order equation of epoxide was proved and the activation energy was calculated to be 27.13 KJ/mol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonates Epoxides Crown ether Salen complexes Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Until now, fossil fuels like coal, natural gas and oil continue to be the world's most important sources of energy [1]. Due to the over-reliance on fossil energy, the content of CO2 in the atmosphere is increasing, having already broken the record of 419 ppm, and will continue to rise in the coming years which has caused a number of environmental problems [2]. In fact, CO2 is an abundant, inexpensive and nontoxic chemical feedstock [3–5]. Therefore, while vigorously developing new clean energy, actively implementing CO2 capture, storage and resource utilization technologies is consistent with society's sustainable development strategy. The production of widely used cyclic carbonates by immobilizing CO2 into epoxy compounds represents a viable method to help solve this problem [6–9]. However, CO2 is also thermodynamically stable (ΔHf =−393.5 kJ/mol) [10]. This reaction overcomes the recalcitrant nature of CO2 by the energy released (∼114 kJ/mol) during the epoxide ring opening process [11]. In this context, various catalysts and catalytic systems were developed to promote this reaction, including homogeneous [12–37] and heterogeneous catalysts [38–61]. A plenty number of homogeneous catalysts have been used, because they can allow the reaction to proceed under modest conditions, sometimes at ambient temperature and air pressure [62]. Nevertheless, difficulties in recovering the homogeneous catalyst from the reaction mixture after the reaction have led researchers to develop heterogeneous catalysts over the last few decades [9,63]. In heterogeneous catalysis, it not only compensates for the disadvantage that homogeneous catalysts are not easy to recover, but also makes it possible to precisely control the active sites. The catalytic sites of porous organic polymers (POPs), such as the pore structure, heteroatoms, etc., can be fine-tuned, resulting in a more enhanced catalytic activity [2]. Depending on the concrete application, high-level specific polymers can be synthesized by adjusting the geometric shape of the pores and the chemical environment in the pores. For example, the novel amine-anchored covalent triazine aromatic polymerization CTP-2-NH2 with tetrabutylammonium bromide (n-Bu4NBr) synthesized by Ravi et al. exhibited superior epoxide conversion in CO2 fixation reaction [64]. Zhang et al. have developed a series of mesoporous organic polymers that can be used in cyclic carbonate generation reactions [65]. The bifunctional multiphase catalysts prepared by Parodi et al. were active in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and epoxides [66]. The interaction between crown ethers host and potassium ion guest is an important secondary interaction to build new materials [67]. Previous studies have confirmed that crown ether can coordinate potassium ions, thereby activating I − and efficiently catalyzing the conversion of CO2 with epoxides [68]. Fu et al. prepared a sequence of amphiphilic quaternary ammonium salts (ZTQAs) with different lengths of alkyl chains bound to KI and regarded them as homogeneous catalytic systems for the coupling reactions of carbon dioxide with various terminal epoxides, among which DTPs/KI showed excellent PC yields at high temperatures (125 °C) [69]. Roshan et al. reported that the histidine/KI homogeneous catalytic system was capable of chemically fixing CO2 at a high temperature of 120 °C [70]. Xiao et al. showed that the triethanolamine/KI homogeneous catalytic system is also effective for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides at 120 °C [71]. All these demonstrate that KI can only obtain the desired results in homogeneous catalytic systems under such severe conditions as high temperatures or in the presence of activated ligands. A variety of transition metals (such as cobalt, copper, manganese, etc.) can be coordinated by Salen ligands, which possess different valence states, coordination numbers, and chemical structures to form [M(Salen)] compounds [72,73]. [M(Salen)] complexes can be bound with other raw materials to upgrade or supplement their original nature, and can also be used as building units to build new supermolecule systems [74]. For example, Ng et al. designed and prepared Co(II)@cage, Co(III)@cage and Al(III)@cage M-Salen molecular cages, revealing that they can successfully immobilize CO2 into styrene oxide [75]. Co(III)-Salen immobilized cellulose nanocrystals prepared by Hu et al. can convert CO2 and epoxide into cyclic carbonate under mild conditions [76]. Liu et al. used (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES) to modify cellulose nanofibers (CNF) and then synthesized salicylaldehyde Schiff bases, which were then liganded with chromium chloride, to generate a new type of cellulose nanofiber (CNF)-loaded (Salen)Cr(III) complexes, which performed excellently in the CO2 immobilization reaction [77]. In the last two decades, Salen compounds and their metal complexes have been widely used in the field of homogeneous catalysis [32–34]. Therefore, a better catalytic system of CO2 cycloaddition can be achieved through the heterogenization of Salen complexes. In this work, Co-Salen complexes bearing different acid groups were combined with coordinated potassium iodide 18-crown-6 to form three Co-Salen-based porous organic catalysts (K@SC-1, K@SC-2, K@SC-3) as shown in Scheme 1 . This kind of catalyst has high catalytic performance for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with various epoxides at 90 °C and 1 bar CO2. This may contribute to the synergy effect of Lewis acid sites and I anion. Experimental section The synthesis of Salen ligand Putting 2.97 g (11.2 mmol) of cyclohexanediamine tartrate, 3.16 g (22.9 mmol) of 99% K2CO3, and 15 mL of deionized water into a three-necked round bottom flask, stir to dissolve thoroughly, then 60 mL of anhydrous ethanol was added until a white flocculent precipitate appears after that 3.6 mL of 3‑tert-butylsalicylaldehyde was added dropwise and reflux for 2 h at 90 °C. When the reaction is completed, leave to stand until a solid is formed. The resulting solid was filtered, dissolved in 100 mL of dichloromethane, after separating the liquid with distilled water and saturated sodium chloride, dry the organic phase with anhydrous magnesium sulfate to remove the moisture and finally rotary evaporated at 30 °C to remove the excess solvent and dry it at a temperature of 60 °C in a vacuum oven for 12 h to gain a yellowish solid. Synthesis of cobalt-Salen complexes 2.94 g of Salen ligand and 1.2 g of Co(OAc)2 were dissolved in 30 mL ethanol and refluxed at 85 °C for 7 h. The reaction was completed, the mixture was filtered, and the resulting solid was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain a brick-red solid. Synthesis of SalenCoX Add Co-Salen ligand and acetic acid to a round bottom flask in a molar ratio of 1:1, then add 10 mL of toluene and stir the mixture at 25 °C for 3 h. After the reaction, the excess solvent was evaporated by rotation and dried in the vacuum condition for 12 h at 60 °C to gain a brown solid Co-Salen-OOCCH3. Co-Salen-OTs and Co-salen-OOCCCl3 were produced by a similar method, the difference being that the acetic acid was replaced by p-toluenesulfonic acid or trichloroacetic acid respectively. Synthesis of K@SCs The K@SCs were obtained via one-pot polycondensation reaction. 275 mg of Co-Salen-OOCCH3 (0.5 mmol), 75 mg of paraformaldehyde (2.5 mmol), 465 mg (2.8 mmol) KI and 13.5 mL 1,4-dioxane, and 1.5 mL HOAc were put in a high-pressure autoclave, fully stir, add 0.1972 g of diaminodibenzo-18-crown-6 (0.5 mmol) prepared through the previous references [78,79], and then keep the sealed container at 100 °C for 24 h. After the reaction, cool the autoclave to room temperature, K@SC-1 gathered by centrifugation is washed with deionized water and a mixture of 1,4-dioxane and dichloromethane respectively until the wash-out solution is colorless. Finally, the K@SC-1 catalyst material was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. When the Co-Salen-OOCCH3 was replaced by Co-Salen-OTs and Co-Salen-OOCCCl3 respectively, K@SC-2 and K@SC-3 were produced. CO2 cycloaddition of epoxides A certain amount of K@SCs and epoxide was added to the reaction tube containing magnets, sealed with a rubber stopper, vacuumed, and carbon dioxide was introduced through a balloon, and then the reaction tube was placed in a module with a pre-set temperature for a predetermined time. After the reaction is completed, the remaining CO2 is drained off, the tube is left to cool, and finally, the products are gathered by a membrane separation method. The yields of cyclic carbonate were determined by 1H NMR. Results and discussion The metallosalen complexes usually catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reactions with co-catalysts such as TBAB and TBAI. However, catalytic materials that combined both the cobalt site and 18-C-6 have not been reported yet. Thus, a series of K@SCs (K@SC-1, K@SC-2, K@SC-3) were designed and synthesized by combining cobalt-salen complexes with different groups (Co-Salen-OOCCH3, Co-Salen-OTs, Co-Salen-OOCCCl3) and diaminobenzene-18-crown-6 coordinated with KI. As illustrated in Scheme 1, the SC polymers skeleton was constructed from the multi-components condensation reactions of Co-Salen monomers, paraformaldehyde and diamino benzene-18-crown-6, and in-suit coordination reaction of crown ether with KI. Thus, both fragments were connected with methylene group originating from the paraformaldehyde condensation reaction [80]. After being characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XPS, SEM, TGA, FT-IR spectroscopy and 13C CP MAS NMR, the catalytic materials were applied to the study of CO2 cycloaddition and exploring the effect of carrying different functional groups on cobalt electrons as well as investing the effect of crown ethers on the nucleophilicity of iodide ions. Furthermore, the synergistic effect in the process of CO2 cycloaddition was also investigated. Catalyst characterization The FT-IR spectra of K@SCs, diaminodibenzo-18-crown-6 and Co-Salen were depicted in Fig. 1 a and Fig. S1. By comparison, almost identical peaks were detected in FT-IR spectra of the K@SCs, the characteristic bands at 559.5, 1258 and 1643 cm−1 are originated from the Co-O, CN and C = N band in Salen ligand [81,82]. The stretching vibration peak at 1122 cm−1 belongs to CO in crown ether [83]. The signal at 3439.5 cm−1 is associated with NH stretching, which links Salen to crown ether. The results of FT-IR spectra indicated that the polymers maintain the structure of the Salen and crown ether. In order to obtain information on the thermal stability of the samples, subsequently, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine the temperature at which the degradation of the synthesized K@SCs polymers began. As shown in Fig. 1b, three polymers exhibited almost feature identical TGA cures. No significant weight loss was observed until 292.34 °C, the temperature at which decomposition of the polymer backbone occurs, demonstrating high thermal stability. K@SCs were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to understand their morphology. As shown by Fig. 2 , it can be observed that three polymers have different morphology. The surface of K@SC-1 is composed of a number of irregular microspheres, and K@SC-2 possesses a vermicular structure, both of them have smooth surfaces. The morphology of K@SC-3 is different from the other two catalytic materials, the surface of K@SC-3 is composed of a number of irregular fluffy nanoparticles connected, somewhat like marshmallows, which makes it easier to adsorb CO2. It is conjectured that because K@SC-1 and K@SC-2 contain more iodine ions, the iodine ions block the pores of the polymer and make the surface smoother. This conjecture was confirmed by ICP-OES tests, described in Table S1, where the iodide ion contents were 0.498, 0.382 and 0.341 mmol/g, respectively. The K@SC-3 was characterized by 13C CP MAS NMR to further confirm the synthesized polymer skeleton structure. As exhibited in Fig. 3 , the signal at 163 ppm originated from C8 of Salen units and the sign at 161 ppm is attributed to the C4 of phenoxyl attached to the oxygen atom [82,84]. A characteristic peak can be seen at 147.21 ppm, which is assigned to the C15 on the benzene ring [58]. The three relatively weak peaks at 134, 131 and 124 ppm represent C2, C1 and C13 as well as C3 and C5 respectively. The peak at 110.8 ppm is assigned to C14 [58,82,84]. A strong peak at 68.13 ppm corresponding to C10, C11 in Salen and C16–19 in crown ether [58,82,84]. The peaks at 48, 30 and 25 ppm are ascribed to C6, C7 in Salen and C12 in the methylene linker respectively [81,82,84,85]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was selected to identify the elemental ingredients on the surface of K@SC-3, detected in Fig. 4 . As expected, the full XPS spectrum signals of C, N, O, I and Co with K@SC-3 can be observed clearly (Fig. 4a). In the high-resolution C1s spectrum (Fig. 4b), CC and C = O bands originating from OOCCCl3 are located in 284.7 and 289 eV [70,78]. Three peaks are sensed in the N1s spectrum in Fig. 4c at 397.3, 399.3 and 402.4 eV, which are ascribed to Co-N, C = N and Ar-N type nitrogen atoms, respectively [76,81]. One distinct peak at 532.6 eV in O1s (Fig. 4d) is related to the CO [58,86]. Two signals with binding energies of 617.8 and 629.3 eV against I3d5/2 and I3d3/2 are included in the I3d spectrum in Fig. 4e [58]. For comparison, the I3d spectrum derived from KI in pure form was depicted in Fig. S2, with a significant change from 619 eV to I3d5/2 and 630.5 eV to I3d3/2, respectively. In particular, the Co2p XPS spectrum matched with two peaks situated in 780.7 and 795.5 eV (Fig. 4f). The former is attributed to Co2p3/2 and the latter to Co2p1/2 [81,85]. Finally, In order to analyze textural properties of the catalyst of K@SC-3, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis was conducted. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was shown in Fig. 5 a, with type III adsorption isotherm confirmed. In the relative pressure scale of 0.1 to 0.97, tangible hysteresis loops were clearly observed, indicating the presence of mesopores in the organic polymer [86]. A steep rise in the adsorption isotherm between 0.9 and 1.0 p/p0, proving that there are macropores in the catalyst. This result is in agreement with the pore size distribution diagram calculated by BJH (Barrett-Joiner-Halenda) model (Fig. 5b), where the main pore edge signal is located at 69.8 nm, which is macroporous. Synthesis of cyclic carbonates As the three catalysts prepared differed in the functional groups they carried, it was necessary to determine which functional group held the best catalytic effect for the CO2 fixation reaction. As expected, all catalysts of K@SCs were effective in catalyzing CO2 with epichlorohydrin (ECH) cycloaddition reaction. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the yields of 41.1% and 5.3% were detected for the uncomplexed KI-derived catalyst SC or the KI-catalyzed cycloaddition reaction alone, respectively. Moreover, when the diaminodibenzo-18-C-6 complex KI was used as a homogeneous catalyst to catalyze the reaction under the same conditions, the conversion rate was merely 28.1%. In contrast, the synthesized materials of K@SCs, all cycloaddition rates above 50% were obtained under the same reaction conditions. It is worth mentioning that the yield of 86.2% obtained from the catalytic reaction of material K@SC-3 is the best among the three materials (57.6% to K@SC-1, 69.7% to K@SC-2). The difference in the catalytic effect of the three materials of K@SCs may be related to the varied Lewis acidicity. The electron-withdrawing ability is ordered as CCl3COO−> p-C7H7SO3 − > CH3COO−, resulting in a stronger electrophilicity of Co3+ in K@SC-1, which in turn leads to relatively higher catalytic activity. At the same time, p-toluenesulphonic acid possesses a large spatial obstacle, causing a lower catalytic activity than K@SC-3. Therefore, the catalytic material K@SC-3 is considered to be the best catalytic material for catalytic CO2 cycloaddition reactions. The catalytic activity is sensitive to the processing temperature, catalyst dosage and processing time of the reaction system, thus it is vital to explore the optimum reaction parameters. The fixation of CO2 with ECH is still favored as the model reaction. The influence of temperature over the reaction was first examined, as manifested in Fig. 6b, it was observed that the yield of the product increases gradually with increasing temperature. The yield rises from 45.7% to 93.2% under reaction conditions of 50–90 °C, proving that the high temperature is beneficial to overcome the aforementioned CO2 inertia. Thus 90 °C was determined as the optimal processing temperature. Furthermore, the amount of catalyst is also a great influence factor in the process of cycloaddition of CO2. As unveiled in Fig. 6c, when the catalyst dosage was increased from 50 mg to 80 mg in a 10 mg gradient, the product yield rose sharply from 57.2% to 95.6%. It is known from previous reports that the activation sites in catalyst play an indispensable role in promoting the cycloaddition reaction, and more catalyst amount means more activation sites in the reaction system, which is why the yield grows with the higher catalyst dosage [87]. Further increasing the catalyst dosage to 90 mg resulted in little change in the yield, which increased only to 96.5%. Therefore, 80 mg is the optimum catalyst dosage. In addition, the impact on reaction time was explored. From Fig. 6d, it was observed that the conversion rate of epoxides increased rapidly from 0 to 87% in the first 16 h of the reaction. The yield slowly improved to 96.2% when the reaction time continued to be extended to 24 h. When the reaction time was 28 h the yield was 97%, which was almost no increase compared to 24 h. As a result, 24 h was determined as the ideal reaction time. The prevalence of K@SC-3 was also explored, which is inspired by the outstanding catalytic activity of K@SC-3 in the described above reaction. As illustrated in Table 1 , it is pleasing to note that corresponding cyclic carbonates can be obtained from the reaction substrates studied, with yields of more than 90% for all substrates except cyclohexene oxide, (Table 1, 2h) which only achieves 58% as a consequence of its large spatial site resistance. Epoxy compounds containing halogen atoms (Table 1, 2a and 2e) are readily converted in a short period of time because of the electron absorption effect. The electron-absorbing functional group reduces the electron cloud density of the Cβ-O bond in the epoxide and contributes to the ring opening of catalytically polarized epoxides [59,88]. The larger molecules of allyl glycidyl ether (Table 1, 2c), n‑butyl glycidyl ether (Table 1, 2f) and aliphatic epoxides (Table 1, 2g) are able to achieve higher conversions, perhaps the result of the high electronegativity of the oxygen atom on the long carbon chain, which attracts electron clouds from neighboring groups and is more susceptible to attack by nucleophilic reagents leading to ring opening [89]. Excitingly, the large molecular size of styrene oxide (Table 1, 2d) with a bulky benzene ring, which has no effect, and glycol diglycidyl ether (Table 1, 2b), which has two rings, also achieved high yields without increasing the temperature, underlining the superiority of the K@SC-3 catalyst. The reusability and recyclability of a catalyst system are crucial factors determining whether it could be applied in industry. To test the properties of the catalyst, recycling experiments were conducted over K@SC-3 under the above-filtered optimization conditions, and ECH/CO2 was selected as a representative reaction. After one cycle, the catalyst is precipitated from the mixture by the addition of ethyl acetate, centrifuged and then washed with propylene oxide, dried and used directly in the next reaction. Fig. 7 summarizes the cyclic results, the catalyst performed equivalent activity of six consecutive cycles with a slight loss of activity, which may be related to the apparent leaching of the catalyst during use. Then FT-IR analysis was performed on the recovered catalyst after the sixth cycle. Almost identical IR curves are found in Fig. S3 for the FT-IR spectra of the fresh and recycled catalysts respectively, explaining the considerable stability of the catalyst throw after cycling many times. The reaction of CO2 to epoxides is commonly known to have a high activation energy and therefore a catalyst is required to reduce the activation energy (Ea) of this reaction. In order to calculate the activation energy of this reaction catalyzed by K@SC-3, kinetic studies were performed at different temperatures varied from 50 to 80 °C. Catalyst-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 is usually stated as Eq. (1), where [PO], [CO2], [Cat.] refer to the concentration of the epoxide, CO2 and catalyst respectively, and α, β and γ indicate the reactant order. Eq. (1) can be abbreviated as Eq. (2), since CO2 is usually in excess while the catalyst is usually quantitative, where k obs = k[CO2] β [Catalyst] γ and k means rate constants. The reaction is known from previous reports to be a first-order reaction [59,90], thus the reaction process is assumed to be a first-order reaction, leading to Eq. (3), which was integrated to give Eq. (4), and leads to Eq. (5), where x meaning conversion rate and (1-x) means [PO]. Four corresponding reaction rate constants k obs were obtained by testing the kinetic data at four different temperatures as depicted in Table S2–5 and Fig. 8 . Eq. (7) is obtained by a logarithmic variation of the Arrhenius Eq. (6). The k obs obtained by the above mentioned at different temperatures were calculated to correspond to lnk obs values and 1/T values, T representing temperature, and fitted as shown in Table S6 and Fig. 9 a, which calculated an Ea of 27.13 KJ/mol in Fig. 9b. A plausible mechanism was proposed in scheme 2 , initially, Lewis acidic Co center which coordinates with the oxygen of the epoxide, polarizing its CO bond (step 1). Simultaneously, the nucleophilic halogen atom iodine attacks the terminal carbon atom of epoxide, causing the ring to open (step 2). Subsequently, CO2 is embedded by means of its electrophilic carbon atoms interacting with the generated oxygen anion (step 3). Finally, the target product cyclic carbonate is produced by intramolecular cyclization, while at the same time, the halogen ions immediately leave and regenerate the catalyst of K@SCs (step 4), that is why the catalyst can be recycled several times. Conclusion In summary, a series of catalytic materials K@SCs were designed and synthesized, which contain Co-Salen ligands with different functional groups and 18-crown-6 rich in amino functional groups. The complexation of potassium iodide into the backbone improves the rigidity of the polymer The model reaction of CO2 with ECH catalyzed by K@SC-3 under optimal reaction conditions (90 °C, 1 bar CO2, 80 mg catalyst usage, 24 h) and without solvent or co-catalyst achieved a high conversion of 96.5%. Furthermore, the catalyst is a promising catalyst for industrial applications, with little loss of catalytic activity after six cycles. A broad range of cyclic carbonates can be produced from respective epoxides esters in >90% yield, offering extensive substrate suitability. The activation energy of this catalytic reaction (CO2/ECH coupling reaction) is 27.13 KJ/mol by kinetic calculations, which greatly reduces the activation energy of this reaction. Studies have shown that positive cobalt lewis acid ions and nucleophilic iodide ions have a strong influence on cyclic carbonate production. This work opens up further possibilities for the multiphase utilization of the homogeneous catalyst Salen in CO2 conversion and provides new guidance toward the design of polymers with high activity. coredata.dc:description: Metallosalen presents very important applications in both homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis. Correspondingly, porous polymeric metallosalen combined with the performance of organometallics and heterogeneous polymers possess potential in CO2 fixation reactions. Herein, a family collection of K@SCs were conceived and obtained by combining cobalt-salen complexes with different groups and diaminobenzene-18-crown-6 complexed with KI, which allows multiphase catalytic immobilization of CO2 to epoxides. Catalyst K@SC-3 can fix CO2 into a variety of substituted epoxides in >90% yields to the corresponding cyclic carbonates in co-catalyst-free and solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, K@SC-3 can be recovered and reused at least six times by simple centrifugal separation, demonstrating superior stability. The kinetics experiments were also carried out at varied temperatures catalyzed by K@SC-3. It is concluded that a first-order equation of epoxide was proved and the activation energy was calculated to be 27.13 KJ/mol.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt−Salen complexes bearing crown ether as metal-templated catalyst for cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and epoxide
